author: Michael Koziol
title: Malcolm Turnbull urged to review rules after slamming 'cult' of excessive CEO pay
text:
Turnbull slams excessive CEO pay Turnbull slams excessive CEO pay 
Malcolm Turnbull has taken his criticism of Australia Post boss Ahmed Fahour's $5.6 million pay packet, a step further. Courtesy 3AW. More videos Is this man worth $5.6 million? 
It's been revealed the head of Australia Post Ahmed Fahour is paid $5.6 million a year and it has made the PM and many other MPs angry. Courtesy ABC News 24, Sky. 
"I think there are lot of corporate CEOs, by the way, that are overpaid," the Prime Minister told Melbourne's 3AW. "I think it has become almost a cult of excessive executive, CEO remuneration." 
When opposition leader in 2008, Mr Turnbull campaigned for a binding vote for shareholders that would allow them to determine in advance the amount of money a board of directors could pay itself and company executives. Related Content 'Give me a break!': Malcolm Turnbull slams 'cult' of excessive CEO pay 
At the outset of the global financial crisis, he told Parliament Australians were "appalled" by the level of executive salaries and were "even more astonished that shareholders' opinions can be ignored". 
Britain has a binding vote system in place every three years and Conservative Party Prime Minister Theresa May is now advancing plans to make it annual for some or all companies. Advertisement 
Edward John, executive manager of governance at the Australian Council of Superannuation Investors, said a binding vote "should be considered among other options as part of a wide-ranging review" of the rules around executive pay. 
"It's hard to find a magic bullet but we'd certainly welcome a debate on what tools are available to investors," he said. "I think many investors would welcome [the Prime Minister's] sentiments." SHARE
